title: The Lewallen Brothers
text:
The Lewallen Brothers were an American <a href="garage%20rock">garage rock</a> <a href="musical%20ensemble">band</a> formed in <a href="Tucson%2C%20Arizona">Tucson, Arizona</a> in 1962. Combining an element of <a href="folk%20rock">folk rock</a>, similar to the sound of <a href="the%20Beau%20Brummels">the Beau Brummels</a>, with the essence of a raw garage band, the group became immensely popular in Arizona. Though the Lewallen Brothers never broke through to a national audience, the band is noted for being one of the longest-enduring garage musical acts to emerge from the 1960s, as the group performed well into the 1990s.
History.
Formed in 1962, the group was originally known as the CoKats, and consisted of brothers Cal (<a href="bass%20guitar">bass guitar</a>, <a href="vocals">vocals</a>) Keith (<a href="lead%20guitar">lead guitar</a>, vocals), Tim (<a href="rhythm%20guitar">rhythm guitar</a>, vocals) and Bobby Lewallen (<a href="organ%20%28music%29">organ</a>, vocals). The band soon recruited Dennis Gamble (<a href="drums">drums</a>), and were occasionally joined by their sister Gayle Ann (vocals) and father Cal senior (bass guitar), while boasting a repertoire that featured material from <a href="the%20Everly%20Brothers">the Everly Brothers</a>, <a href="Chuck%20Berry">Chuck Berry</a>, and <a href="the%20Ventures">the Ventures</a>. With an established presence on the teen <a href="dance%20club">dance club</a> and bar circuit, the CoKats entered the studio to record four demos on November 14, 1964. From the sessions, the song "Tough He Was" was presented to <a href="record%20producer">record producer</a> <a href="Bob%20Keane">Bob Keane</a>, who released the tune on the group's debut <a href="single%20%28music%29">single</a>, and convinced the CoKats to change their name to the Lewallen Brothers.
By the mid-1960s, the group was opening for musical acts such as <a href="the%20Turtles">the Turtles</a>, <a href="the%20Beau%20Brummels">the Beau Brummels</a>, and <a href="Paul%20Revere%20and%20the%20Raiders">Paul Revere and the Raiders</a>. Ironically, the hard-pressed schedule that came with the Lewallen Brothers being a live musical act consequently impeded the group from recording consistently. Music critic Bruce Eder explains "Their impeccable harmony singing, coupled with their considerable instrumental prowess and their tight sound, made them highly desireable [sic] both as a warm-up act as well as a backing band". In 1967, the band released the two singles "It Must Be a Dream" and "Only a Dream", both of which were met with regional success. After winning a battle of the bands contest in 1968, the group earned an appearances on <a href="Dick%20Clark">Dick Clark</a>'s television program "<a href="Happening%20%2768">Happening '68</a>", competing on three shows. However, without a nationally distributing <a href="record%20label">record label</a> to back them, the Lewallen Brothers could not capitalize on the exposure.
In 1969, Gamble departed the band and was replaced by Mike Ramsey. The band returned to Tucson, becoming the house band for the Cedars <a href="music%20club">music club</a>, with the brothers also working part-time as <a href="plumbers">plumbers</a> in their family business. In 1981, the Lewallen Brothers went on a decade-long hiatus after Bobby Lewallen died from <a href="cancer">cancer</a>. Returning in the early 1990s without Tim Lewallen, who decided to become a plumber full-time, the band occasionally performed around Arizona. The <a href="compilation%20album">compilation album</a> "Hitch-Hike" was released in December 1995, and featured all the group's recorded material. Other albums the band appears on include "The Cicadelic Sixties, Volume 7 - From Texas to Tucson!", ', ', "The Tucson Sound 1960–1968: Think of the Good Times!", and "Wyld Sydes, Volume 4".
